questions.text: A 22-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 4 hours after the ingestion of 25 tablets of an unknown drug. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 41/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 88/55 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 93%. She is confused and oriented only to person. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Examination shows cold, clammy extremities. Scattered expiratory wheezing and rhonchi are heard throughout both lung fields. The abdomen is soft. Fingerstick blood glucose concentration is 65 mg/dL. ECG shows prolonged PR intervals and narrow QRS complexes. Two large-bore cannulas are inserted, and intravenous normal saline, dextrose, and atropine are administered. Five minutes later, pulse is 51/min, and blood pressure is 95/61 mm Hg. In addition to securing the airway, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Intravenous glucagon is part of the initial treatment for symptomatic patients with beta blocker overdose with no response to IV fluids and atropine alone. Excessive beta-adrenergic blockade most commonly manifests as bradycardia and hypotension. In severe cases, profound myocardial depression and cardiogenic shock can occur. Glucagon increases intracellular cAMP by activating adenylate cyclase, which improves cardiac contractility while bypassing the beta receptors. Additional treatment depends on the severity of symptoms and may include administration of vasopressors (to correct hypotension), intravenous calcium (to treat cardiogenic shock), high-dose insulin (positive inotropic effect), and glucose (to treat hypoglycemia), and intravenous lipid emulsion therapy (to prevent further absorption of beta blocker).

B) INCORRECT:

Activated charcoal may be used in acute poisoning to bind medications in the gastrointestinal tract and prevent their absorption. However, activated charcoal is effective within a maximum of 1–2 hours of ingestion. It would therefore likely not be effective in this patient. While administration of activated charcoal may still be considered once the airway has been secured, a different step in management is indicated more urgently.

C) INCORRECT:

While sodium bicarbonate is used to treat propranolol overdose, it is not effective in the treatment of other types of beta blocker toxicity. In addition to the typical manifestations of beta blocker toxicity, propranolol causes QRS widening due to sodium channel blockade, whereas this patient has narrow QRS complexes. Sodium bicarbonate may also be used to treat the arrhythmias associated with sodium channel inhibition in patients with tricyclic antidepressant toxicity. In patients with toxicity due to barbiturates, salicylates, and a number of other drugs, sodium bicarbonate can be used to alkalinize the urine, thereby enhancing the excretion of these substances.

D) INCORRECT:

Hemodialysis may be used in severe cases of toxicity with hydrophilic beta blockers (e.g., atenolol, nadolol). However, hemodialysis in these cases would be considered only after first-line management failed.

E) INCORRECT:

Pralidoxime is used in the treatment of cholinergic syndrome (e.g., caused by organophosphate poisoning). Although this syndrome can cause bradycardia and wheezing (due to bronchoconstriction), other typical manifestations of this syndrome would also be expected, such as diarrhea, uncontrolled urination, miosis, salivation, and sweating. Furthermore, this patient's hypoglycemia would not typically occur in cholinergic syndrome.

F) INCORRECT:

Naloxone is the first-line treatment for opioid overdose and can also be used in the treatment of clonidine toxicity. While both types of toxicity can present with bradycardia, hypotension, and CNS depression, they also cause miosis and hypothermia, which are not seen in this patient.

G) INCORRECT:

Digoxin-specific antibody fragments (Fab) are the treatment of choice for digitalis poisoning. However, digitalis toxicity typically presents with nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and blurry vision with a yellow tint.
questions.hint: Bradycardia, hypotension, wheezing, confusion, hypoglycemia, and prolonged PR intervals strongly suggest severe beta blocker intoxication.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man comes to the physician because of anxiety, difficulty focusing on tasks, and a 4.6-kg (10-lb) weight loss over the past 4 weeks. He is diaphoretic. His pulse is 100/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 150/78 mm Hg. Physical examination shows warm, moist skin, goiter, and a resting tremor of both hands. Laboratory studies show a thyroxine (T4) concentration of 30 μg/dL and a thyroid-stimulating hormone concentration of 0.1 μU/mL. The patient is started on methimazole and atenolol. The latter agent predominantly affects which of the following?

choices.text: Effective refractory period of the cardiac action potential
Phase 0 depolarization slope of the cardiac action potential

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

β1 adrenergic receptor antagonists lower concentrations of cAMP and calcium in the cells of the atrioventricular (AV) node. This decreases conduction and automaticity at the AV node by decreasing the slope of phase 4 depolarization of the nodal (pacemaker) action potential. On ECG this effect would appear as a prolonged PR interval. Beta blockers also have a negative chronotropic (↓ risk of heart failure) and a negative inotropic (↓ contractility) effect.
Image Description:

Illustration of membrane potential of the atrioventricular node over time for class II antiarrhythmic drugs.

Normal action potential is shown faded. Class II antiarrhythmic drugs extend the time until the threshold potential is reached and prolong depolarization and are therefore negative dromotropic (slow down conduction speed).

B) INCORRECT:

Atenolol acts on β1 receptors to decrease sympathetic tone. It has no effect on vagal (parasympathetic) tone. Digoxin is an antiarrhythmic that can increase vagal tone.

C) INCORRECT:

Prolongation of the effective refractory period of the cardiac action potential is caused by Class IA, IC, III, and IV antiarrhythmic drugs. Beta-blockers (class II antiarrhythmics), however, do not significantly alter the refractory period.

D) INCORRECT:

Class I antiarrhythmics can decrease conduction in extranodal tissue (e.g., His-Purkinje system). Beta blockers do not act on the His-Purkinje system.

E) INCORRECT:

Phase 0 depolarization slope of the cardiac action potential is caused by the opening of fast voltage-gated Na+ channels. Class I antiarrhythmics, which block these channels, would, therefore, affect phase 0. Beta-blockers (class II antiarrhythmics) do not affect Na+ channel activity and do not have any effect on phase 0. They instead decrease the slope of phase 4 depolarization.
questions.hint: Atenolol is a cardioselective beta blocker, which competitively antagonizes the positive chronotropic, inotropic, and dromotropic effect of catecholamines.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman comes to the physician because of involuntary hand movements that improve with alcohol consumption. Physical examination shows bilateral hand tremors that worsen when the patient is asked to extend her arms out in front of her. The physician prescribes a medication that is associated with an increased risk of bronchospasm. This drug has which of the following immediate effects on the cardiovascular system?



Stroke volume
Heart rate
Peripheral vascular resistance



A
↑
↑
↓


B
↓
↓
↓


C
↓
↑
↑


D
↓
↓
↑


E
↑
↑
↑
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hydralazine and other arterial vasodilators can have this immediate physiologic profile (i.e., increased stroke volume and heart rate, decreased peripheral vascular resistance). These drugs lead to vasodilation, which lowers systemic vascular resistance and causes reflex tachycardia and an increase in stroke volume. However, these medications are not indicated for treating essential tremor.

B) INCORRECT:

Alpha-2 agonists and beta blockers with alpha-1 receptor blocking properties can cause these immediate physiologic changes (i.e., a decrease in stroke volume, heart rate, and peripheral vascular resistance) because they are negatively inotropic, negatively chronotropic, and cause peripheral vasodilation. However, none of these medications are the first-line treatment for essential tremor.

C) INCORRECT:

Furosemide causes diuresis and, especially when administered at high doses, activation of the RAAS. The immediate physiologic effects seen following the administration of furosemide include decreased stroke volume (due to reduced plasma volume), increased (or normal) heart rate, and a transient increase in peripheral vascular resistance (due to increased circulating angiotensin II).

D) CORRECT:

As a nonselective beta blocker, propranolol has both beta 1 and beta 2 antagonistic effects. Beta-1 receptor blockade has a negative chronotropic effect (lowers heart rate) and a negative inotropic effect (reduces stroke volume), which causes a reflex increase in systemic vascular resistance (SVR) to preserve blood pressure. Beta-2 receptor blockade causes an additional increase in SVR. The overall reduction in blood pressure, if any, is mild because the reduction in cardiac output is mitigated by the increase in SVR.

A similar effect is seen in alpha-1 agonists, such as phenylephrine, which cause an increase in SVR with reflex bradycardia and decreased stroke volume.

E) INCORRECT:

High-dose epinephrine or dopamine would cause these immediate physiologic changes because they are positive chronotropes, positive inotropes, and activate alpha-1 receptors, which leads to increased SVR. These drugs, however, are not treatment options for essential tremor.
questions.hint: A postural tremor that improves with alcohol consumption is characteristic of essential tremor. Propranolol, a nonselective beta blocker that is typically the first-line drug for essential tremors, is associated with an increased risk of bronchospasm, which limits its use in patients with asthma or COPD.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with coronary artery disease comes to the physician because of intermittent episodes of substernal chest pain and shortness of breath. The episodes occur only when walking up stairs and resolves after resting for a few minutes. He is a delivery man and is concerned because the chest pain has impacted his ability to work. His pulse is 98/min and blood pressure is 132/77 mm Hg. Physical examination is unremarkable. An ECG shows no abnormalities. A drug that blocks which of the following receptors is most likely to prevent future episodes of chest pain from occurring?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Alpha-2 adrenergic receptor blockade would worsen this patient's chest pain by increasing the release of catecholamines in the presynaptic neurons of the sympathetic nervous system. This, in turn, increases blood pressure (afterload) and workload of the heart, which increases myocardial oxygen demand and consumption. Alpha-2 blockers have limited clinical application and are not used for coronary artery disease. Instead, alpha-2 adrenergic agonists, such as clonidine, are used to treat hypertension.

B) INCORRECT:

Angiotensin II receptor blockade (e.g., ARBs) causes vasodilation, which decreases blood pressure, afterload, and cardiac oxygen demand and consumption. Although these drugs are commonly used in patients post-MI and are proven to decrease mortality rates, ARBs are not used for symptomatic treatment of stable angina.

C) INCORRECT:

Aldosterone receptor blockade (e.g., spironolactone, eplerenone) decreases sodium reabsorption and inhibits hydrogen and potassium excretion in the collecting ducts of the kidneys. These agents are commonly used in heart failure and are proven to decrease mortality rates. However, aldosterone antagonists are not used for symptomatic treatment of stable angina.

D) INCORRECT:

M2 muscarinic receptor blockade would worsen this patient's chest pain by decreasing parasympathetic activity in the AV node, which increases heart rate, cardiac workload, and myocardial oxygen demand and consumption. Muscarinic antagonists (e.g., atropine) are first-line agents for the treatment of symptomatic bradycardia (e.g., third-degree AV block).

E) CORRECT:

Beta-1 adrenergic receptor blockade decreases heart rate and cardiac contractility (negative chronotropic and inotropic effect, respectively). This, in turn, decreases blood pressure and myocardial oxygen demand, and therefore anginal symptoms. Beta-1 receptor blockade also decreases AV node conduction (increased refractory period), giving drugs targeting this receptor an antiarrhythmic effect.
questions.hint: This patient has stable angina and will benefit from a drug that reduces myocardial oxygen demand.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 3 hours after ingesting approximately 30 tablets of an unknown drug in an apparent suicide attempt. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 40/min, respiratory rate is 19/min, and blood pressure is 85/50 mm Hg. Examination shows cold, clammy extremities. Scattered expiratory wheezing is heard throughout both lung fields. His fingerstick blood glucose concentration is 62 mg/dL. ECG shows prolonged PR intervals and narrow QRS complexes. Intravenous fluid resuscitation and atropine do not improve his symptoms. Administration of which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although sodium bicarbonate is used to treat propranolol overdose, it is not effective in the treatment of other types of beta-blocker toxicity. In addition to the typical manifestations of beta-blocker toxicity, propranolol causes QRS widening due to sodium channel blockade. This patient's narrow QRS complexes are unlikely caused by propranolol.

Sodium bicarbonate is also an antidote to barbiturates, salicylates, tricyclic antidepressants, and a number of other drugs. It works by stabilizing the cardiac membrane (mostly in widened QRS) and also by alkalizing the urine and enhancing the excretion of these substances.

B) INCORRECT:

Pralidoxime is used in the treatment of cholinergic syndrome. Although this syndrome can cause bradycardia and wheezing (due to bronchoconstriction), other typical manifestations such as sweating, lacrimation, or urination (SLUDGE-M) would also be expected in this patient. Furthermore, hypoglycemia is not a common manifestation of cholinergic syndrome.

C) CORRECT:

In patients with beta-blocker overdose, intravenous glucagon should be administered when blood pressure and heart rate do not respond sufficiently to IV fluids and atropine alone. Glucagon increases intracellular cAMP by activating adenylate cyclase, which improves cardiac contractility and heart rate while bypassing the beta receptors. It also improves hypoglycemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Activated charcoal may be used in acute poisoning to bind medications in the gastrointestinal tract and prevent their absorption. However, it is only effective within 1–2 hours (maximum) following ingestion of the poisonous substance. Activated charcoal would not be useful for this patient who presented 3 hours after ingestion of the tablets.

E) INCORRECT:

Digoxin-specific antibody fragments are the treatment of choice for digitalis poisoning, which typically manifests with nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, diarrhea, blurry vision with a yellow tint, and cardiac arrhythmias. While digitalis toxicity can also cause bradycardia and hypotension, wheezing (indicating bronchoconstriction) and hypoglycemia are not consistent with this condition.

F) INCORRECT:

Naloxone is the first-line treatment for opioid overdose, which can present with mild bradycardia and hypotension. However, intoxication with opioids usually also presents with decreased respiratory rate and miosis, which are not seen in this patient. Wheezing and prolongation of the PR interval are not consistent with opioid overdose.
questions.hint: Bradycardia, hypotension, wheezing, hypoglycemia, and prolonged PR intervals suggest severe beta-blocker overdose.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination after a recent change in her medication regimen. She reports that she feels well. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, hypertension, essential tremor, and chronic back pain. Current medications are metformin, glyburide, propranolol, simvastatin, ramipril, amitriptyline, and ibuprofen. Fingerstick blood glucose concentration is 47 mg/dL. Serum studies confirm this value. Which of the following pharmacologic mechanisms is most likely responsible for the absence of symptoms in this patient?

choices.text: Inhibition of norepinephrine and serotonin reuptake
Blockade of potassium channels in pancreatic β-cells

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ibuprofen reversibly inhibits COX-1 and COX-2 enzymes and is commonly prescribed for patients with chronic back pain. Ibuprofen can cause an increased risk of gastrointestinal inflammation, but it does not interfere with the sympathetic nervous system or symptoms of hypoglycemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Amitriptyline, a tricyclic antidepressant, inhibits the reuptake of norepinephrine and serotonin and is effective in patients with diabetic neuropathy and chronic pain. While amitriptyline is used with caution in older adults because of its anticholinergic properties and potential for sedation, it does not interfere with the symptoms of hypoglycemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Glyburide blocks potassium channels in pancreatic beta cells, which induces insulin release and can cause hypoglycemia in certain settings, such as reduced caloric intake or when taken with other glucose-lowering drugs. However, glyburide has no effect on the sympathetic nervous system and would not interfere with this patient's neuroglycopenic symptoms.

D) CORRECT:

Antagonism of β2-adrenergic receptors is the mechanism of propranolol, a nonselective beta blocker that is commonly used for essential tremor as in this patient. Nonselective beta blockers should be used with caution in patients with diabetes mellitus, as they can facilitate hypoglycemia in two ways. First, a drop in serum glucose activates the sympathetic nervous system to release epinephrine, which stimulates β2-adrenergic receptors in the liver, leading to increased gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis. However, nonselective beta blockers block this counterregulatory mechanism, resulting in a more severe drop in glucose. Furthermore, epinephrine induces early warning signs of hypoglycemia, such as sweating, palpitations, and anxiety; nonselective beta blockers blunt these symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Ramipril is an ACE inhibitor that is used for management of hypertension and can also be cardioprotective in certain patient populations. ACE inhibitors do not mask the symptoms of hypoglycemia.

F) INCORRECT:

Simvastatin is a statin that works by inhibiting HMG-CoA reductase, an enzyme involved in cholesterol synthesis. Commonly prescribed for hyperlipidemia, simvastatin's major side effects are related to liver and muscle tissue. Statins have no effect on the sympathetic nervous system.
questions.hint: Symptoms of hypoglycemia include tremor, palpitations, and anxiety, and are caused by activation of the sympathetic nervous system.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of intermittent palpitations that occur when he is stressed, exercising, or when he drinks alcohol. Physical examination shows an irregularly irregular pulse. An ECG shows irregular QRS complexes without any discrete P waves. Pharmacotherapy with carvedilol is initiated for his condition. Compared to treatment with propranolol, which of the following adverse effects is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hyperkalemia can occur as a side effect of beta blockers, especially in patients with pre-existing impaired potassium excretion or with beta blocker overdose. It is caused by two different mechanisms: First, β-adrenergic blockade impairs urinary potassium excretion by inhibiting the secretion of renin, which in turn decreases aldosterone synthesis. Second, beta blockers directly decrease cellular uptake of potassium by inhibiting Na+/K+-ATPase. As both carvedilol and propranolol are non-selective beta blockers, hyperkalemia is a possible side effect of both.

B) CORRECT:

As beta blockers are class II antiarrhythmic drugs, carvedilol can be administered to lower heart rate by reducing AV conduction velocity. However, because of its α-blocking action, carvedilol also inhibits α1-adrenergic receptors of blood vessels, which leads to relaxation of smooth muscle and thus vasodilation. This decreases peripheral vascular resistance, which in turn reduces preload and afterload and might cause orthostatic hypotension. This adverse effect is not observed in propranolol, which does not have an α-blocking effect, but only blocks β1, β2, and β3 receptors.

C) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of ß1 receptors on cardiac muscle tissue decreases heart rate and can lead to bradycardia. However, this effect may be observed in all beta blockers, including carvedilol and propranolol, since they all block ß1 receptors.

D) INCORRECT:

Blockade of ß2 receptors in pancreatic cells impairs insulin release, which lowers cellular glucose uptake. Through this mechanism, non-selective beta blockers can cause hyperglycemia with impaired glucose tolerance or even new-onset diabetes. As both carvedilol and propranolol are non-selective beta blockers, hyperglycemia is a possible side effect of both.

E) INCORRECT:

Non-selective beta blockers inhibit ß1, ß2, and ß3 receptors. Since ß2 receptors are found in bronchiolar smooth muscle, these beta blockers can cause bronchospasm. As both carvedilol and propranolol are non-selective beta blockers, bronchospasm is a possible side effect of both.
questions.hint: This patient presents with symptoms that indicate atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (palpitations, irregular pulse, ECG showing irregular QRS complexes, and indiscernible P-waves). Carvedilol is a nonselective beta blocker with additional α-blocking action.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of episodic retrosternal chest pain and shortness of breath for the past 6 months. His symptoms occur when he takes long walks or climbs stairs but resolve promptly with rest. He has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, for which he takes ipratropium bromide. His pulse is 81/min and blood pressure is 153/82 mm Hg. Physical examination shows mild expiratory wheezing over both lungs. Additional treatment with a beta blocker is considered. Which of the following agents should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Atenolol is a beta blocker with selectivity for beta-1 receptors. It would not be contraindicated in this patient with COPD.

B) INCORRECT:

Esmolol is a beta blocker with selectivity for beta-1 receptors. It would not be contraindicated in this patient with COPD.

C) CORRECT:

Labetalol is a nonselective beta blocker that inhibits both beta-1 receptors and beta-2 receptors. The negative inotropic and chronotropic effects of beta-1 receptor antagonism would decrease myocardial oxygen demand. This is beneficial in patients with angina. However, inhibition of beta-2 receptors would lead to bronchoconstriction, which would decrease FEV1 and worsen air trapping in patients with obstructive lung diseases such as COPD and asthma. Therefore, nonselective beta blockers (e.g., labetalol, propranolol, nadolol, pindolol, timolol, carvedilol) should be avoided in this group of patients.

D) INCORRECT:

Metoprolol is a beta blocker with selectivity for beta-1 receptors. It would not be contraindicated in this patient with COPD.

E) INCORRECT:

Betaxolol is a beta blocker with selectivity for beta-1 receptors. It would not be contraindicated in this patient with COPD.

F) INCORRECT:

Bisoprolol is a beta blocker with selectivity for beta-1 receptors. It would not be contraindicated in this patient with COPD.
questions.hint: This patient presents with symptoms of chronic stable angina and a history of COPD. Treatment with nonselective beta blockers should be avoided.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after her husband found her unconscious on the living room floor. She does not report having experienced light-headedness, nausea, sweating, or visual disturbance before losing consciousness. Three weeks ago, she was diagnosed with open-angle glaucoma and began treatment with an antiglaucoma drug in the form of eye drops. She last used the eye drops 1 hour ago. Examination shows pupils of normal size that are reactive to light. An ECG shows sinus bradycardia. This patient is most likely undergoing treatment with which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Latanoprost, a prostaglandin F2α agonist analog, decreases intraocular pressure by increasing the outflow of aqueous humor. Common side effects include discoloration of the iris, eyelids, and conjunctiva as well as blurred vision, watering/burning, and foreign body sensation. Bradycardia is not an adverse effect of latanoprost.

B) CORRECT:

Timolol is a nonselective beta blocker that is used as an ophthalmic formulation for the treatment of open-angle glaucoma. It blocks ß2 receptors in the ciliary body of the eye, decreasing aqueous humor production and consequently lowering intraocular pressure. However, because timolol is passively absorbed into the systemic circulation from the eye, it has high bioavailability, potentially leading to systemic side effects such as the blockade of ß1 receptors in the heart and subsequent negative ionotropic and chronotropic effects. In excess, these effects can cause bradyarrhythmias and orthostatic hypotension, both of which can lead to syncope, as seen in this patient.

Nonselective beta blockers also cause bronchoconstriction, especially in patients with reactive airway disease, and should be used with caution in patients with asthma.
Image Description:

PGF2α analogues (e.g., latanoprost)
– Reduce outflow resistance of trabecular meshwork
– Increase uveoscleral outflow by relaxing ciliary muscle and disrupting turnover of extracellular matrix

β-blockers (e.g., timolol): diminish aqueous humor production by inhibiting Na+/K+ ATPase

α2 agonists (e.g., brimonidine)
– Reduce episcleral venous pressure
– Diminish aqueous humor production by inhibiting Na+/K+ ATPase

Cholinomimetics (e.g., pilocarpine)
– Widen trabecular meshwork via ciliary muscle activation
– Open up the iridocorneal angle by activating the iris sphincter muscle (miosis)

Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (CAI; e.g., acetazolamide): diminish aqueous humor production

Rho-kinase inhibitors (e.g., netarsudil)
– Increase trabecular outflow
– Lower episcleral venous pressure
– Decrease aqueous humor production by increasing noradrenergic transmission

C) INCORRECT:

Dorzolamide, a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor, reduces aqueous humor production. Common side effects include an ocular burning sensation, pruritus, lacrimation, blurred vision, and a bitter taste, but bradycardia is not a known side effect.

D) INCORRECT:

Apraclonidine reduces intraocular pressure by decreasing aqueous humor production. While apraclonidine is associated with bradycardia in rare cases, other side effects, e.g., ocular hyperemia, pruritus, foreign body sensation, and blurry vision, are more common.

E) INCORRECT:

Tropicamide, an anticholinergic medication, is used commonly as a mydriatic agent. Pupillary dilation can precipitate angle-closure glaucoma in predisposed individuals and is contraindicated in patients with glaucoma. Moreover, tachycardia, not bradycardia, is a side effect of tropicamide, making a different agent more likely.

F) INCORRECT:

Pilocarpine, a cholinergic agonist that primarily acts on M3 muscarinic receptors, reduces intraocular pressure by increasing the trabecular outflow of aqueous humor. Pilocarpine can cause bradycardia, which could explain this patient's syncope. However, pilocarpine also causes sweating, nausea, blurred vision and pupillary constriction, none of which are seen in this patient.
questions.hint: This drug decreases adenylate cyclase activity. It is used to treat glaucoma because it decreases aqueous humor synthesis.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of blurry vision for the past 3 days. He has also had 4 episodes of right-sided headaches over the past month. He has no significant past medical history. His father died of coronary artery disease at the age of 62 years. His temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 94/min, and blood pressure is 232/128 mm Hg. Fundoscopy shows right-sided optic disc blurring and retinal hemorrhages. A medication is given immediately. Five minutes later, his pulse is 75/min and blood pressure is 190/105 mm Hg. Which of the following drugs was most likely administered?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Intravenous labetalol, an adrenergic blocker with nonselective beta antagonism (β1 and β2 receptors) and alpha-1 antagonism, is used to treat severe gestational hypertension and hypertensive emergencies. Alpha-1 blockade causes peripheral vasodilation, which decreases blood pressure. Beta-1 receptor blockade decreases cardiac contractility and renin secretion, which further lowers blood pressure. In addition, beta-1 blockade decreases heart rate by causing sinoatrial and AV node depression.

Carvedilol and the nondihydropyridine calcium channel blocker diltiazem can cause a similar decrease in both blood pressure and heart rate. Antihypertensives that only have a vasodilatory effect (e.g., hydralazine, nitroprusside, nicardipine, fenoldopam) cause an increase in heart rate (reflex tachycardia).

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous hydralazine, which is a direct vasodilator that mainly affects peripheral arteries, can be used to treat hypertensive emergencies. However, the administration of hydralazine causes reflex tachycardia rather than the decrease in heart rate seen here. Fluid retention, angina, and drug-induced lupus can also occur as a result of hydralazine administration.

C) INCORRECT:

Fenoldopam is an intravenously administered D1-receptor agonist that is used to treat hypertensive emergencies. Fenoldopam causes the vasodilation of peripheral vessels and promotes natriuresis but its administration would result in reflex tachycardia rather than the decrease in heart rate seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

Intravenous nicardipine, a dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker (CCB), is used to treat hypertensive emergencies. Dihydropyridine CCBs primarily decrease the contractility of vascular smooth muscle cells and lower blood pressure by decreasing peripheral vascular resistance. However, the administration of dihydropyridine CCBs causes reflex tachycardia rather than the decrease in heart rate seen here. Dihydropyridine CCBs can also cause peripheral edema and flushing. As a result of sinoatrial or AV node depression, a decrease in heart rate can occur following the administration of nondihydropyridine CCBs (e.g., verapamil, diltiazem).

E) INCORRECT:

Intravenous nitroprusside, which causes arterial and venous dilation via the release of nitric oxide, is used to treat hypertensive emergencies. However, the administration of nitroprusside causes reflex tachycardia rather than the decrease in heart rate seen here. Cyanide toxicity and methemoglobinemia can also occur following nitroprusside administration.
questions.hint: This patient is experiencing a hypertensive emergency, which is characterized by an acute increase in blood pressure (> 180/120 mm Hg) and signs of end-organ damage (e.g., blurry vision, headaches, retinal flame hemorrhages, papilledema). He was treated with a medication that decreases heart rate and systemic vascular resistance.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 4 hours after the ingestion of 25 tablets of an unknown drug. Pulse rate is 41/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 88/55 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 93%. She is confused. Examination shows cold, clammy extremities. Scattered expiratory wheezing and rhonchi are heard throughout both lung fields. Fingerstick blood glucose measurement shows hypoglycemia. Electrocardiography shows prolonged PR intervals and narrow QRS complexes. Two large-bore cannulas are inserted, and intravenous normal saline, dextrose, and atropine are administered. Five minutes later, pulse is 51/min, and blood pressure is 95/61 mm Hg. In addition to securing the airway, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Intravenous glucagon is part of the initial treatment for symptomatic patients with beta blocker overdose with no response to IV fluids and atropine alone. Excessive beta-adrenergic blockade most commonly manifests as bradycardia and hypotension. In severe cases, profound myocardial depression and cardiogenic shock can occur. Glucagon increases intracellular cAMP by activating adenylate cyclase, which improves cardiac contractility while bypassing the beta receptors. Additional treatment depends on the severity of symptoms and may include administration of vasopressors (to correct hypotension), intravenous calcium (to treat cardiogenic shock), high-dose insulin (positive inotropic effect), and glucose (to treat hypoglycemia), and intravenous lipid emulsion therapy (to prevent further absorption of beta blocker).

B) INCORRECT:

Activated charcoal may be used in acute poisoning to bind medications in the gastrointestinal tract and prevent their absorption. However, activated charcoal is effective within a maximum of 1–2 hours of ingestion. It would therefore likely not be effective in this patient. While administration of activated charcoal may still be considered once the airway has been secured, a different step in management is indicated more urgently.

C) INCORRECT:

Hemodialysis may be used in severe cases of toxicity with hydrophilic beta blockers (e.g., atenolol, nadolol). However, hemodialysis in these cases would be considered only after first-line management failed.

D) INCORRECT:

Pralidoxime is used in the treatment of cholinergic syndrome (e.g., caused by organophosphate poisoning). Although this syndrome can cause bradycardia and wheezing (due to bronchoconstriction), other typical manifestations of this syndrome would also be expected, such as diarrhea, uncontrolled urination, salivation, and sweating. Furthermore, this patient's hypoglycemia would not typically occur in cholinergic syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Digoxin-specific antibody fragments (Fab) are the treatment of choice for digitalis poisoning. However, digitalis toxicity typically presents with nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and blurry vision with a yellow tint.
questions.hint: Bradycardia, hypotension, wheezing, confusion, hypoglycemia, and prolonged PR intervals strongly suggest severe beta blocker intoxication.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the office because of episodic retrosternal chest pain and shortness of breath for the past 6 months. His symptoms occur when he takes long walks or climbs stairs but resolve promptly with rest. He has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, for which he takes ipratropium bromide. Additional treatment with a beta blocker is considered. Which of the following agents should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Betaxolol is a beta blocker with selectivity for beta-1 receptors. It would not be contraindicated in this patient with COPD.

B) INCORRECT:

Bisoprolol is a beta blocker with selectivity for beta-1 receptors. It would not be contraindicated in this patient with COPD.

C) CORRECT:

Labetalol is a nonselective beta blocker that inhibits both beta-1 receptors and beta-2 receptors. The negative inotropic and chronotropic effects of beta-1 receptor antagonism would decrease myocardial oxygen demand. This is beneficial in patients with angina. However, inhibition of beta-2 receptors would lead to bronchoconstriction, which would decrease FEV1 and worsen air trapping in patients with obstructive lung diseases such as COPD and asthma. Therefore, nonselective beta blockers (e.g., labetalol, propranolol, nadolol, pindolol, timolol, carvedilol) should be avoided in this group of patients.

D) INCORRECT:

Esmolol is a beta blocker with selectivity for beta-1 receptors. It would not be contraindicated in this patient with COPD.

E) INCORRECT:

Atenolol is a beta blocker with selectivity for beta-1 receptors. It would not be contraindicated in this patient with COPD.
questions.hint: This patient presents with symptoms of chronic stable angina and a history of COPD. Treatment with nonselective beta blockers should be avoided.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man presents with progressively worsening dyspnea. He has a 3-year history of systolic heart failure. One month ago, echocardiography showed an ejection fraction of 30%. His medications include a low-dose ACE inhibitor, a loop diuretic, and spironolactone. He does not have bradyarrhythmias or reactive airway disease. Physical examination shows jugular venous distension and bilateral basilar crackles.


Heart rate
85/min


Blood pressure
120/80 mm Hg


Which treatment modification is most appropriate to improve his survival and reduce hospitalizations?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Digoxin enhances myocardial contractility and can reduce hospitalizations by improving cardiac performance. However, it does not improve survival in systolic heart failure. While it may provide symptomatic relief, it lacks the mortality benefit seen with therapies targeting the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system and sympathetic nervous system.

B) INCORRECT:

Hydralazine, an arterial vasodilator, reduces afterload and can improve symptoms. It is beneficial in combination with nitrates for African-American patients or those intolerant to ACE inhibitors or ARBs. This patient is on an ACE inhibitor without contraindications, and hydralazine alone does not significantly improve survival or reduce hospitalizations in heart failure.

C) INCORRECT:

Loop diuretics alleviate symptoms of volume overload, such as jugular venous distension and crackles, by reducing fluid retention. However, they do not improve survival or reduce hospitalizations in systolic heart failure. Increasing diuretic doses can lead to electrolyte imbalances and renal dysfunction without addressing the underlying pathophysiology, such as maladaptive remodeling and neurohormonal activation.

D) CORRECT:

Beta-adrenergic blockers, such as bisoprolol, significantly improve survival and reduce hospitalization rates in patients with systolic heart failure. They mitigate the harmful effects of chronic sympathetic stimulation, which leads to adverse myocardial remodeling and increased arrhythmogenic potential. Clinical trials have demonstrated that bisoprolol improves left ventricular function when titrated to target doses in heart failure with reduced ejection fraction. In patients without contraindications like bradyarrhythmias or reactive airway disease, bisoprolol is a cornerstone therapy for reducing morbidity and mortality.

Key learning point: In heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, beta-blockers such as bisoprolol are essential for improving survival and reducing hospitalizations, and should be added if not already part of the treatment regimen.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man presents with an acute ST-elevation myocardial infarction and is started on aspirin and reperfusion therapy. Which mechanism best explains how metoprolol improves survival in this setting?

choices.text: Promotes rapid collateral vessel development, enhancing perfusion
Decreases heart rate and contractility, reducing myocardial oxygen demand
Inhibits platelet function, preventing further thrombus formation
Dilates coronary arteries, significantly increasing coronary blood flow

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Metoprolol does not promote rapid collateral vessel development. Its benefit in myocardial infarction is through reducing myocardial oxygen demand by decreasing heart rate and contractility, not angiogenesis.

B) CORRECT:

Metoprolol, a beta-1 selective antagonist, decreases heart rate and myocardial contractility, reducing myocardial oxygen demand. This reduction is crucial during an acute myocardial infarction, as it limits ischemic injury and infarct expansion. Additionally, metoprolol stabilizes cardiac rhythm and decreases arrhythmia risk by lowering sympathetic tone, contributing to improved survival.

Key learning point: Beta-blockers like metoprolol improve survival in patients with myocardial infarction by reducing myocardial oxygen demand and limiting infarct size.

C) INCORRECT:

Metoprolol does not inhibit platelet function. Its benefits in myocardial infarction are due to beta-1 blockade, reducing heart rate and contractility, unlike aspirin, which directly affects platelet function.

D) INCORRECT:

Metoprolol does not significantly dilate coronary arteries. Its survival benefit in myocardial infarction is due to reduced myocardial oxygen demand through decreased heart rate and contractility, not direct coronary vasodilation.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man with poorly controlled asthma develops new hypertension and requires pharmacotherapy. Which medication is contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lisinopril is an ACE inhibitor that lowers blood pressure by reducing angiotensin II formation and promoting vasodilation. Although it can cause a dry cough due to bradykinin accumulation, this side effect is mechanistically different from bronchospasm and does not exacerbate asthma.

B) CORRECT:

Propranolol is a non-selective beta-blocker that antagonizes both β1-adrenergic receptors in the heart and β2-adrenergic receptors in bronchial smooth muscle. Blockade of β2 receptors impairs bronchodilation, increasing the risk of bronchospasm in patients with reactive airway diseases such as asthma. In patients with asthma, alternative antihypertensive medications that selectively target β1 receptors or use different mechanisms, such as ACE inhibitors or calcium channel blockers, are preferred to avoid compromising pulmonary function.

Key learning point: Non-selective beta blockers are contraindicated in patients with poorly controlled asthma due to the risk of bronchoconstriction.

C) INCORRECT:

Amlodipine is a dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker that lowers blood pressure through vasodilation without affecting beta-adrenergic receptors. It does not provoke bronchoconstriction, making it safe for patients with asthma.

D) INCORRECT:

Bisoprolol is a beta-blocker with high beta1 selectivity, preferentially inhibiting cardiac beta1 receptors with minimal activity on beta2 receptors in bronchial smooth muscle. Its beta1 selectivity reduces the risk of bronchoconstriction in asthmatic patients, unlike non-selective beta-blockers.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 6-month history of episodic retrosternal chest pain and shortness of breath. His symptoms occur during long walks or when climbing stairs and resolve promptly with rest. He has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and is taking ipratropium bromide. You are considering additional treatment with a beta blocker. Which one of the following agents should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Esmolol is a beta blocker with selectivity for beta-1 receptors. It would not be contraindicated in this patient with COPD.

B) INCORRECT:

Bisoprolol is a beta blocker with selectivity for beta-1 receptors. It would not be contraindicated in this patient with COPD.

C) INCORRECT:

Atenolol is a beta blocker with selectivity for beta-1 receptors. It would not be contraindicated in this patient with COPD.

D) CORRECT:

Labetalol is a nonselective beta blocker that inhibits both beta-1 receptors and beta-2 receptors. The negative inotropic and chronotropic effects of beta-1 receptor antagonism would decrease myocardial oxygen demand. This is beneficial in patients with angina. However, inhibition of beta-2 receptors would lead to bronchoconstriction, which would decrease FEV1 and worsen air trapping in patients with obstructive lung diseases such as COPD and asthma. Therefore, nonselective beta blockers (e.g., labetalol, propranolol, nadolol, pindolol, timolol, carvedilol) should be avoided in this group of patients.

Key learning point: Nonselective beta blockers should be avoided in patients with COPD due to the risk of bronchoconstriction from beta-2 receptor blockade.

E) INCORRECT:

Betaxolol is a beta blocker with selectivity for beta-1 receptors. It would not be contraindicated in this patient with COPD.
questions.hint: This patient presents with symptoms of chronic stable angina and a history of COPD. Treatment with nonselective beta blockers should be avoided.
